# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

```julia
function audi_filter(df)
    df_filtered = df[df.manufacturer .== "audi", :]
    
    # Check for models a4 or a4 quattro
    model_conditions = [
        df_filtered.model .== "a4",
        df_filtered.model .== "a4 quattro"
    ]
    
    # Create new column with true for matching conditions
    df_filtered[!, "audi_a4_
assistant... _type"] .= any(model_conditions, dims=2)) ? true : false
    
    return df_filtered
end

# Test the function with the given data
df_cars_filtered = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
The `audi_filter` function filters the DataFrame based on the manufacturer and model conditions. It then creates a new column indicating whether the row matches the criteria or not.

After defining the function, you can test it by passing the `df_cars` DataFrame to `audi_filter`. The resulting filtered DataFrame will be stored in `df_cars_filtered`.
